Notes: Policy: As of 5 a.m. on 20th April 2021, Schools and Day Cares may be open to provide care of children of essential workers. Otherwise, schools remain closed.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426212611/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-schools

As of 9 May 2021,  Public and private schools and Bermuda College are open.  Licenced/registered Day Care Centres and Day Care Providers are open.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511114737/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-schools

Policy: Remote working will continue to be required. However, retail stores (including pet stores) and restaurants are open to curb-side, take-out, and delivery service only. Grocery stores and gas stations must operate with no more than 20% capacity and must abide by an alphabet system further describe in the cited source.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426212216/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions

From 9 May  Restaurants open for outdoor dining and not dining indoors.  Retail stores to open for in-store customers and the standard is a maximum of 20% of the store's occupancy capacity. Gyms are open with equipment to be spaced 6ft apart.  Barber shop, beauty salons spas massage, therapists are prohibited from providing services which require face masks to be removed.  working from home is no longer mandatory but strongly encouraged.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511114750/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions

Policy: Given that the mixing of households is prohibited and large public venues (clubs, indoor movie theaters, museums, bowling alleys, etc.) are not allowed to operate, this component was coded at a 2G.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426212216/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426214438/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-recreation

Wedding, funerals and religious services:   (indoor) number of person cannot exceed 20% of seating capacity up to a max of 25 persons.   (outdoor) max 25 persons.    Limited numbers for gatherings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511114750/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions
Policy: No recent updates.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426212216/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions
limited numbers for gatherings (no more than 10 people with physical distancing in place)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511114750/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions
Policy: No recent updates.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426212216/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions

Is public transportation operating?  Yes  When traveling on public buses and ferries, all passengers must wear masks, sit three feet away from others, sanitize their hands upon entry, and follow capacity limitation rules.  Visitors should only take public transportation if you need to.   Leisurely rides are not recommended.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210511120637/https://bm.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/

Policy: As of 5am on Tuesday April 20th 2021 there is a night-time curfew from 8pm to 6am and the below guidance must be followed.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426212216/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions

As of 6am on Sunday May 9th 2021 there is a night-time curfew from 10pm to 5am and the below guidance must be followed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511114926/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-recreation
Policy: No policies related to internal movement were included in the recent update.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426212216/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  No  However, the Government of Bermuda has published guidance and regulations pertaining to immunized and non-immunized travelers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511120637/https://bm.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/

Policy: Commercial airlines may return to Bermuda, but there are specific testing requirements to replace the requirement to quarantine for 14 days.  Both visitors and residents must apply for a Travel Authorisation Form, 48 hours before departing for Bermuda. All travellers to Bermuda who are arriving from the United Kingdom or who have visited the United Kingdom in the 14 days before they arrive in Bermuda must quarantine in their accommodation for four days. They may only be released from quarantine after the receiving a negative result from the Day 4 COVID-19 test all travellers to the island must take.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426212216/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions

Effective immediately, all travellers to Bermuda who are arriving from Brazil, India or South Africa or who have visited Brazil, India or South Africa in the 14 days before they arrive in Bermuda must quarantine in their accommodation for fourteen days. They may only be released from quarantine after receiving a negative result from the Day 14 COVID-19 test.  In this case, quarantine relates to the property at which the traveler is accommodated, if the traveller is immunised, however if the traveler is not immunized they must stay in the room.  Effective Wednesday, 5th May all non-immunised travellers to Bermuda must quarantine in their accommodation for four days. They may only be released from quarantine after receiving a negative result from the Day 4 COVID-19 test. In this case, quarantine relates to the property at which the traveller is staying, not a single room.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210511120637/https://bm.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/
No updates.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426220810/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-premiers-remarks-20-april-2021
Updates are regularly delivered on this site which also features links to various relevant sources.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511114750/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions
https://web.archive.org/web/20210511122107/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-get-tested
https://web.archive.org/web/20210511122149/https://www.gov.bm/quarantine-contact-tracing

This mask requirement includes, but is not limited to:    Workers at all workplace premises - in accordance with the relevant  guidance    Passengers onboard public transport or in taxis     When visiting any establishment (indoor or outdoor) (e.g. grocery store, shop, bank, office, gallery etc) unless otherwise allowed by specific guidance.    School children in accordance with the relevant guidance    In public places (streets or parks) when other people are present and 6feet distance cannot be maintained.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511122537/https://www.gov.bm/mask-guidance

Bermuda’s National COVID-19 vaccination strategy has as its primary priority for the COVID-19 vaccination programme the prevention of COVID-19 mortality and the protection of health care workers, essential workers and social care staff and systems.  Secondary priorities include vaccination of those at increased risk of hospitalisation, at increased risk of exposure, and to maintain resilience in public services.  (A,B,C)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511122640/https://www.gov.bm/covid-19-vaccine-allocation-strategy
Current curfew regulations also apply to the elderly.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210511114750/https://www.gov.bm/new-outbreak-restrictions

On 23 april 2021, elementary and secondary schools are closed for in-class learning with classes online in the province of Ontario; in the Gatineau and Quebec City regions of the province of Quebec; Regina, capital of the province of Saskatchewan; Edmundston in the province of New Brunswick; in the territory of Nunavut, Iqaluit capital city. In Alberta, grades 7-12 students have moved to online learning in many cities. Most post-secondary institutions in Canada have been offering online classes during this academic year. See CBC news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422180839/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/edmonton-public-catholic-schools-move-grades-7-to-12-online-as-covid-19-cases-surge-1.5995643

On 3 may 2021, elementary and secondary schools are closed for in-class learning with classes online in the provinces of Ontario and Nova Scotia; in the Gatineau region of the province of Quebec; in the territory of Nunavut, Iqaluit capital city. In some regions of Alberta and Quebec, high school students have moved to online learning. Most post-secondary institutions in Canada offered online classes during the past academic year and are continuing to do so for summer courses. See Globe and Mail plus CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501203104/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/covid-19-update-nova-scotia-april-27-1.6003300  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501201813/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 7 may 2021, elementary and secondary schools are closed for in-class learning with classes online in the provinces of Ontario, Nova Scotia and Alberta; in the Gatineau region of the province of Quebec; in the territory of Nunavut, Iqaluit capital city; in the Northwest territory, Yellowknife capital city. Most post-secondary institutions in Canada offered online classes during the past academic year and are continuing to do so for summer courses. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210506192144/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 17 may 2021, elementary and secondary schools are closed for in-class learning with classes online in the provinces of Ontario, Nova Scotia and Alberta; in Manitoba, Winnipeg and Brandon (2 most populous cities); the territory of Nunavut, Iqaluit capital city; in the Northwest territory, Yellowknife capital city. High school classes are online in some regions of the province of Quebec. Many post-secondary institutions in Canada offered online classes during the past academic year and are continuing to do so for summer courses. See CTV news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517112655/https://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/with-school-likely-to-remain-virtual-for-many-students-this-year-focus-should-be-on-the-fall-expert-1.5423151

On 21 may 2021, elementary and secondary schools are closed for in-class learning with teaching online in the provinces of Ontario, Nova Scotia and Alberta; in Manitoba, Winnipeg and Brandon (2 most populous cities); the territory of Nunavut, Iqaluit capital city; in the Northwest territory, Yellowknife capital city. High school classes are online in some regions of the province of Quebec. Many post-secondary institutions in Canada offered online classes during the past academic year and are continuing to do so for summer courses. See CBC news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210520155442/https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/coronavirus-covid19-canada-world-may19-2021-1.6032212

On 23 april 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. “Non-essential” businesses are closed in the province of Ontario; in the province of Quebec, Gatineau and Quebec City regions;  in the province of New Brunswick, Edmundston area; in the territory of Nunavut, Iqaluit capital city. Critics argue that definition of “non-essential” is too narrow in some jurisdictions. In other jurisdictions, most businesses are open with restrictions. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210418151917/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423111838/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-medical-experts-call-for-closure-of-more-businesses-in-ontario/

On 3 may 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. “Non-essential” businesses are closed in the provinces of Ontario and Nova Scotia (NS); in the province of Quebec, Gatineau region; in the territory of Nunavut, Iqaluit capital city. In other jurisdictions, businesses are open with restrictions. See Globe and Mail newspaper and province of NS websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501201813/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210428212804/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/restriction-updates/

On 7 may 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. “Non-essential” businesses are closed in the provinces of Ontario and Nova Scotia (NS); in the province of Quebec, Gatineau region; in the territory of Nunavut, Iqaluit capital city. In other jurisdictions, businesses are open with restrictions. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210506192144/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 17 may 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. “Non-essential” businesses are closed in the provinces of Ontario and Nova Scotia (NS); in the province of Quebec, Gatineau/Outaouais region and some regions bordering USA; in the territory of Nunavut, Iqaluit capital city. In other jurisdictions, businesses are open with restrictions. See Retail Council of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517113350/https://www.retailcouncil.org/coronavirus-info-for-retailers/

On 21 may 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. “Non-essential” businesses are closed in the provinces of Ontario and Nova Scotia (NS); in the province of Quebec, Estrie, Chaudière-Appalaches, Bas-Saint-Laurent regions;  in the territory of Nunavut, Iqaluit capital city. In other jurisdictions, businesses are open with restrictions. See Retail Council of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210520162131/https://www.retailcouncil.org/coronavirus-info-for-retailers/provincial-covid-19-resources-and-updates/

On 23 april 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Effective 8 April, the province of ONtario decreed: “Meeting and event spaces: Closed”. Other jurisdictions have imposed similar rules, but not all -- e.g., some provinces allowing public events with rules. See Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423130421/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 3 may 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Effective 28 April, the province of Nova Scotia (NS) decreed: “no social events, special events, festivals, arts/cultural events, sports events, faith gatherings, wedding receptions, or funeral visitation or receptions”. Other jurisdictions have imposed similar rules, but not all. E.g., some provinces are allowing sports and other public events with rules. See province of NS and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501204637/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20210427003  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501201813/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 7 may 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Ontario: “Indoor & outdoor organized events … are not permitted.” Nova Scotia (NS): “no social events, special events, festivals, arts/cultural events, sports events, faith gatherings, wedding receptions, or funeral visitation or receptions”. Other jurisdictions have imposed similar rules, but not all. E.g., some provinces are allowing sports and other public events with rules. See provinces of NS, Ontario and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210506192144/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210506195142/https://www.toronto.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/9636-COVID-19-Indoor-Outdoor-Events-Gatherings.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501204637/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20210427003

On 17 may 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Ontario: “Indoor & outdoor organized events … are not permitted.” Nova Scotia (NS): “businesses and organizations are not permitted to host events”. Other jurisdictions have imposed similar rules, but not all. E.g., some provinces are allowing sports and other public events with rules. See province of NS and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210515152850/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/restriction-updates/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210515145337/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/toronto/article-toronto-shuts-down-big-summer-events/

On 21 may 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Ontario: “Indoor & outdoor organized events … are not permitted.” Nova Scotia (NS): “businesses and organizations are not permitted to host events”. Other jurisdictions have imposed similar rules, but not all. E.g., some provinces are allowing public events with masking and/or distancing restrictions. See province of NS and City of Toronto websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210520181314/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/restriction-updates/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521125203/https://www.toronto.ca/explore-enjoy/festivals-events/

Effective 23 april 2021, the province of Nova Scotia imposed new restrictions in the Halifax (capital and largest city) region for 4 weeks: “new restrictions limit outdoor and indoor gatherings to five people”. The rules set by each province and territory vary. “Ontarians can’t gather indoors or outdoors with people not in their own households.” Limits are higher in other jurisdictions at lower covid alert levels”. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423130421/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423113941/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-nova-scotia-closes-borders-to-non-essential-travel-from-most-of-canada/

On 3 May 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Effective 28 april 2021, the province of Nova Scotia (NS) extended previous restrictions from the Halifax (capital and largest city) region to the entire province: “Nova Scotians can only gather indoors or outdoors with their household bubble, which is the people they live with; households of two or less people can socialize with one or two others but they must be the same people.” “Ontarians can’t gather indoors or outdoors with people not in their own households.” Limits are higher in other jurisdictions at lower covid alert levels. See Globe and Mail newspaper and province of NS websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501204637/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20210427003  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501201813/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 7 May 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Nova Scotia (NS): “Only your household bubble is allowed to gather indoors and outdoors, though smaller households can have two regular designated contacts.”  “Ontarians can’t gather indoors or outdoors with people not in their own households.” Limits are higher in other jurisdictions at lower covid alert levels. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210506192144/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 17 May 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Nova Scotia (NS): “Gathering limit (indoors and outdoors) is no more than your household bubble (the people you live with). Smaller households with up to 2 people can socialize with 2 additional people, but they must be the same 2 people all of the time. Faith gatherings are not permitted. Wedding ceremonies and funerals can have up to 5 people plus the person conducting the ceremony (receptions and visitation are not permitted).”  “Ontarians can’t gather indoors or outdoors with people not in their own households.” Limits are higher in other jurisdictions at lower covid alert levels. See province of NS and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210515152850/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/restriction-updates/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210506192144/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 21 May 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Nova Scotia (NS): “Gathering limit (indoors and outdoors) is no more than your household bubble (the people you live with). Smaller households with up to 2 people can socialize with 2 additional people, but they must be the same 2 people all of the time. Faith gatherings are not permitted. Wedding ceremonies and funerals can have up to 5 people plus the person conducting the ceremony (receptions and visitation are not permitted).”  Limits are higher in other jurisdictions at lower covid alert levels. See province of NS website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210520181314/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/restriction-updates/

On 19 april 2021, in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), bus transit seating is still restricted below capacity although limits are now higher than when NL was at higher alert levels. The NL limits are mirrored by informal practices in some other jurisdictions -- e.g., “GO (Government of Ontario) Transit, reduced service levels by about 50 per cent as ridership plunged”. See St. John’s and Corner Brook, NL as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422183929/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422184628/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423111838/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-medical-experts-call-for-closure-of-more-businesses-in-ontario/

The NL limits are similar to informal practices in some other jurisdictions -- e.g., “GO (Government of Ontario) Transit, reduced service levels by about 50 per cent as ridership plunged”. See St. John’s and Corner Brook, NL as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501210133/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501210342/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423111838/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-medical-experts-call-for-closure-of-more-businesses-in-ontario/

On 7 may 2021, in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), bus transit seating is still restricted below capacity although limits are now higher than when NL was at higher alert levels. The NL limits are similar to informal practices in some other jurisdictions -- e.g., “GO (Government of Ontario) Transit, reduced service levels by about 50 per cent as ridership plunged”. See St. John’s and Corner Brook, NL as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507141035/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507141106/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423111838/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-medical-experts-call-for-closure-of-more-businesses-in-ontario/

On 17 may 2021, in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), bus transit seating is still restricted below capacity although limits are now higher than when NL was at higher alert levels. The NL limits are similar to informal practices in some other jurisdictions -- e.g., “Ridership on bus trips remains very low. At this time, daily trips do not exceed 50 per cent capacity. As such, it is not necessary to establish a 50 per cent cap on capacity of buses. Halifax Transit will continue to monitor ridership and capacity.” See St. John’s and Corner Brook, NL and Halifax Today websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516011200/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516011117/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516005603/https://www.halifaxtoday.ca/coronavirus-covid-19-local-news/hrm-issues-statement-on-halifax-transit-service-3756268

On 21 may 2021, in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), bus transit seating is still restricted below capacity although limits are now higher than when NL was at higher alert levels. The NL limits are similar to informal practices in some other jurisdictions -- e.g., in Winnipeg, Manitoba transit users have been advised: “Only use Transit for essential trips, such as grocery shopping or getting to work...Consider riding in off-peak hours if possible to help make sure there’s space for everyone who needs it.” See St. John’s and Corner Brook, NL and Winnipeg Transit websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210520182237/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210520182740/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521125845/https://winnipegtransit.com/en/rider-guide/news/winnipeg-transit-response-to-covid-19

As of 23 april 2021, the Province of Quebec continues to enforce an overnight curfew -- 9:30 p.m. to 5 a.m. in most of the province and 8 pm to 5 am in the Gatineau, Quebec City and Montreal regions. Quebec is the only province or territory in Canada with a curfew. Effective 22 April 2021, the province of Nova Scotia (NS) “is placing additional restrictions on travel … people from outside Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland and Labrador will not be allowed to enter Nova Scotia unless their travel is essential or they are permanent residents of Nova Scotia”. The other 3 Atlantic provinces as well as Manitoba continue to impose quarantine requirements on out-of-province visitors including Canadians. Ontario Provincial Police at road boundaries with Manitoba and Quebec are turning away non-Ontarians making non-essential visits. Quebec Provincial Police are doing the same for non-Quebecers seeking to cross at the road boundary with Ontario. See Globe and Mail newspaper and province of NS websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423130421/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423132629/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20210420006

Effective 23 April 2021, the latest restriction on internal movement within Canada is that the province of British Columbia announced and implemented a plan “to establish periodic road checks at key points used for leisure travel to “discourage” people from travelling. Police will have discretion to issue $575 fines under the act... The order targets travel across regional zones for recreational purposes. It is OK to travel for essential reasons, including to attend school or work, transport commercial goods, return to a principal residence, get access to child care, use health care or assist someone in obtaining health care.” Alberta and Saskatchewan are now the only provinces with no internal travel restrictions. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423180503/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-news-in-canada-toronto-peel-region-could-begin-workplace/

As of 3 May 2021, Alberta and Saskatchewan are the only jurisdictions with no travel restrictions whatsoever. Other provinces and territories have quarantine requirements and/or outright bans on interprovincial visitors. British Columbia is restricting non-essential inter-regional travel within the province. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501201813/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501215621/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-atlantic-canadas-strict-quarantine-rules-under-increasing-scrutiny-as/

As of 7 May 2021, Alberta and Saskatchewan are the only jurisdictions with no travel restrictions. Other provinces and territories have quarantine requirements and/or outright bans on interprovincial and/or international visitors. British Columbia is restricting non-essential inter-regional travel within the province. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210506192144/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

As of 17 May 2021: “Significant travel restrictions remain in place in jurisdictions across the country … a number of provinces have imposed restrictions within and between provinces for non-essential travel.” Alberta and Saskatchewan appear to be the only jurisdictions with no restrictions. Other provinces and territories have quarantine requirements and/or outright bans on interprovincial and/or international visitors. “In B.C., public health authorities have divided the province into three travel regions and asked residents not to travel outside their region or the province.” See CBC news website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210516114055/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/summer-vacation-covid-19-travel-restrictions-1.6022536

As of 21 May 2021, Alberta and Saskatchewan continue to be the only jurisdictions in Canada with no travel restrictions of any kind. Other provinces and territories have quarantine requirements and/or outright bans on interprovincial and/or international visitors. “In B.C., public health authorities have divided the province into three travel regions and asked residents not to travel outside their region or the province.” See Government of Canada website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210515041046/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/provinces

On 22 april 2021, Canada’s Transport Minister announced: “suspending all commercial and private passenger flights arriving from the two countries (India and Pakistan) for the next 30 days...The minister also said passengers who travel from India or Pakistan to Canada through an indirect route will need to obtain a negative COVID-19 test from the last country they were in before they arrive in Canada. Cargo flights will be allowed to continue to ensure an uninterrupted supply of vaccines.” Canada’s Health Minister said: “only 1.8 per cent of travellers [from all countries] are found to be positive with COVID-19 ... India accounts for 20 per cent of recent air travel volume to Canada, but more than 50 per cent of all positive tests conducted at the border … a similarly high number of cases compared to travel rates have been linked to Pakistan. ‘We will continue to apply stringent testing and quarantine measures for all passengers arriving in Canada.’ The federal government says all travellers entering Canada are subject to COVID-19 entry screening ... Anyone arriving at the border must isolate for 14 days if they have symptoms of COVID-19. They must also quarantine for 14 days if they do not have symptoms...travellers, unless specifically exempted, are required to demonstrate to a border services officer evidence of a valid test result. Foreign nationals without a valid molecular test or with symptoms of COVID-19 are not allowed entry to Canada. All travellers, whether arriving by land or air are also required to submit their travel and contact information, including a suitable quarantine plan before crossing the border or boarding a flight.” See Globe and Mail website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423110814/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-canada-suspends-flights-from-india-pakistan-due-to-covid-19-variant/

On 28 April 2021, debate within Canada continues on the effectiveness of the government’s measures to close the border with measures restricting and discouraging non-essential travel. Canadian Press reported: “More than 2,000 people returning to Canada since the federal government brought in mandatory hotel quarantines have tested positive for COVID-19 and ... 557 international air travellers tested positive for a variant of concern.…Ottawa has required … since Feb. 22 … air passengers had to spend three days of that (two-week quarantine) in a quarantine hotel. As the variants arose, Canada also began requiring negative COVID-19 tests before boarding a plane, and from air and land border travellers upon arrival...Health Canada … can’t provide test results for any of the 297 people who paid a $3,000 fine for failing to stay in the quarantine hotel...Prime Minister Justin Trudeau defends the government’s policies as among the strongest in the world, and says most of the travellers are Canadians who cannot be refused entry.” See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210429130739/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-news-today-canada-post-temporarily-closes-mississauga-ont/

On 3 may 2021, travel restrictions between Canada and the rest of the world remain in place. “As of April 22, 2021 … Canada is suspending flights from India and Pakistan. To protect Canadians from the outbreak of COVID-19, the Prime Minister announced travel restrictions that limit travel to Canada. Until further notice, most foreign nationals cannot travel to Canada ... These restrictions stop most non-essential (discretionary) travel to Canada....You can travel to and enter Canada if you’re a Canadian citizen; permanent resident of Canada; person registered under Canada’s Indian Act; protected person. Foreign nationals, including United States (US) citizens, can travel to Canada only if they’re eligible...You must also have a quarantine plan that shows how you’ll quarantine for 14 days when you arrive in Canada. This plan is mandatory.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503194039/https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/coronavirus-covid19/travel-restrictions-exemptions.html

In the 7 may 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, the government of Canada responded that ”it has stopped most non-essential foreign travel already, but allows exceptions, including for Canadian citizens, their family members and those travelling for compassionate reasons, as well as international students and foreign workers. It also stopped all direct flights from hard-hit India and Pakistan and requires three negative tests from all international air travellers, who must also stay in quarantine hotels for three nights awaiting test results, then complete a 14-day quarantine at home. Those crossing land borders also require three tests and must follow a quarantine plan reviewed by a border officer. Federal Public Safety Minister Bill Blair said … the current border measures have reduced air traffic by 96 per cent and crossings at the land border by 82 per cent.” Response to media advertisements in which the governing party of the province of Ontario “warns that “mutant COVID variants” are flying into Canada from Britain, South Africa, Brazil and India. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau “didn’t close the borders when the pandemic started. He didn’t close the borders when the pandemic got worse.” See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507134700/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-pcs-demand-border-measures-in-attack-ads/

On 17 may 2021, travel restrictions between Canada and the rest of the world remain in place. “As of April 22, 2021 … Canada is suspending flights from India and Pakistan. To protect Canadians from the outbreak of COVID-19, the Prime Minister announced travel restrictions that limit travel to Canada. Until further notice, most foreign nationals cannot travel to Canada ... These restrictions stop most non-essential (discretionary) travel to Canada....You can travel to and enter Canada if you’re a Canadian citizen; permanent resident of Canada; person registered under Canada’s Indian Act; protected person. Foreign nationals, including United States (US) citizens, can travel to Canada only if they’re eligible...You must also have a quarantine plan that shows how you’ll quarantine for 14 days when you arrive in Canada. This plan is mandatory.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516114448/https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/coronavirus-covid19/travel-restrictions-exemptions.html

On 20 may 2021, Canada’s Public Security Minister tweeted: “We are extending travel restrictions on non-essential international travel and with the United States until June 21st, 2021.” See twitter.com/BillBlair, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210521122608/https://twitter.com/BillBlair/status/1395387860992339968

As of 23 april 2021, the government of Canada continues to pay the Canada Recovery Benefit (CRB) to self-employed Canadians who have lost income. In the 19 April 2021 budget, the government “proposes to extend the maximum eligibility period … by 12 weeks, for a total of 50 weeks, up from the current cap of 38 weeks. While the program is set to run until Sept. 25, Canadians who’ve been continuously receiving the benefit ...would run out of financial support in June under the status quo. For the first four of the 12 additional weeks, Canadians would continue to receive $500 per week worth of pre-tax benefits. For the last eight weeks, however, the benefit would be scaled back to a gross $300 a week, according to the budget document. And starting on July 17, 2021, all new claimants would receive the reduced $300-a-week payment.” Employment Insurance benefits and eligibility rules for formerly employed Canadians continue to be paid on an enhanced basis relative to pre-covid rules. See government of Canada and Global news websites, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210423142518/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423135612/https://globalnews.ca/news/7764150/canada-budget-2021-benefits-taxes-minimum-wage/

As of 23 april 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health agencies follow this guidance to test individuals who report possible symptoms or are possible contacts. In some regions, asymptomatic individuals have been tested during outbreaks, but that practice remains the rare exception, not the general rule. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423153432/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 3 may 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health agencies follow this guidance to test individuals who report possible symptoms or are possible contacts. In some regions, asymptomatic individuals have been encouraged to come forward for mass testing during outbreaks, but that practice remains the exception, not the general rule. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502122428/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 21 may 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health agencies follow this guidance to test individuals who report possible symptoms or are possible contacts. In some regions at some times, asymptomatic individuals have been encouraged to come forward for mass testing during outbreaks, but that practice remains the exception, not the general rule. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521141159/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 23 april 2021, all provinces and territories are doing their best to apply government of Canada guidance that when individuals “test positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.” However, in some regions, contact tracing capacity cannot always keep up with caseloads. For example, the Saskatchewan Health Authority has a policy of “alerting the public about businesses that have likely been exposed to COVID-19 by an infectious person. This is done when health officials are uncertain they have identified all close contacts … within 48 hours”. There were 4 new alerts this week. See Government of Canada and Global news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423153432/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423174045/https://globalnews.ca/news/7347407/coronavirus-saskatchewan-potential-covid-19-exposures/

As of 3 may 2021, all provinces and territories are doing their best to apply government of Canada guidance that when individuals “test positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.” However, in some regions, contact tracing capacity cannot always keep up with caseloads. In the 27 april 2021 print edition, Andre Picard, health policy columnist at the Globe and Mail newspaper, commented that “contact-tracing efforts have proven abysmal”. See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427214443/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-the-death-of-a-child-speaks-volumes-about-canadas-tepid-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502122428/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 7 may 2021, all provinces and territories are doing their best to apply government of Canada guidance that when individuals “test positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.” However, in some regions, contact tracing capacity cannot always keep up with caseloads. For example, on 7 may, CBC news reported: “The [Ottawa] region is in a record-breaking third wave of the pandemic that includes more dangerous coronavirus variants, straining contact tracing …” See Government of Canada and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507143614/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507144234/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/covid19-ottawa-coronavirus-symptoms-information-may-7-2021-1.6017191

As of 17 may 2021, all provinces and territories are doing their best to apply government of Canada guidance that when individuals “test positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.” However, in some regions, contact tracing capacity cannot always keep up with caseloads. For example, in a 12 may Globe and Mail newspaper report: “In Canada, even basic contact tracing has often collapsed when cases are too numerous.” See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516115355/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210514134439/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-how-montreal-has-so-far-dodged-a-third-covid-19-wave-and-what-other/

In the 21 may 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, Ontario’s Chief Medical Officer of Health “said he wanted the province to have schools reopened in June, provided public-health units could handle contact tracing”. This comment suggests continuing doubt that contact tracing capacity can keep up with caseloads in all regions. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210521123256/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-unveils-slow-and-cautious-reopening-plan/

On 3 may 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Provinces and territories require adults and children to wear masks in public spaces. Exceptions in some jurisdictions preclude 3G rating -- e.g., province of British Columbia encourages, but does not require, children in early grades under 4 to wear masks in school. See Government of Canada website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502130501/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html

Provinces and territories require adults and children to wear masks in public spaces. Exceptions in some jurisdictions preclude 3G rating. See Government of Canada website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507150709/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html

See Government of Canada website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210516120004/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html

As of 3 may 2021  2:30PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 12,801,947 Canadians [33.7% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments will not arrive until later. 1,129,882 Canadians [3%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women in Ontario), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, now all seniors wherever they live). AstraZeneca now being administered to ages 40+ in British Columbia, Alberta, Manitoba, Ontario, Saskatchewan and 45+ in Quebec. See CTV news and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503192204/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccination-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503193526/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/

In the 5 May 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, “Prime Minister Justin Trudeau reiterated that Canadians should get the first COVID-19 vaccine they can, contradicting the recommendation from … the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) … that waiting for an mRNA vaccine, like those from Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna, is preferable to receiving a viral vector vaccine, from Johnson & Johnson and AstraZeneca, when personal risk of contracting COVID-19 is lower.” See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506122103/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-trudeau-urges-canadians-to-get-first-covid-19-shot-theyre-offered/

As of 7 may 2021  11:17AM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 13,962,514 Canadians [37% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed pending a quality control check. 1,211,646 Canadians [3%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, now all seniors wherever they live). AstraZeneca now being administered to ages 40+ in British Columbia, Alberta, Manitoba, Ontario, Saskatchewan, Nova Scotia and 45+ in Quebec. See CTV news and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507153424/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccination-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507152811/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/

As of 17 may 2021  2:23PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 17,209,515 Canadians [45% of the total national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca (no longer being offered as a first dose). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed pending a quality control check. 1,417,030 Canadians [4%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations were initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, now all seniors wherever they live). With provinces and territories making vaccinations available to ages at least as young as 40 (Nova Scotia, Newfoundland), code changed to 4 = broad availability. See CTV news and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517192117/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccination-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517193935/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/

As of 21 may 2021  10:21AM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 18,448,382 Canadians [48.5% of the total national population and 55% of the vaccine-eligible population aged 12+] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca (no longer being offered as a first dose). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed pending a quality control check. 1,551,322 Canadians [4% of national total] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations were initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, now all seniors wherever they live). With provinces and territories making vaccinations available to ages at least as young as 40, code now at 4 = broad availability. See CTV news and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521144449/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccination-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521142151/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/

On 23 April, the province of Nova Scotia imposed new restrictions in the Halifax (capital and largest city) region for 4 weeks: “no visitors or volunteers will be allowed inside long-term care facilities, except for designated care providers.” The province of New Brunswick (NB) continues to maintain strict restrictions on visitors, particularly in the Edmundston lockdown area. However, other provinces have relaxed visitor restrictions in long-term care homes now that almost all residents have been vaccinated. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423113941/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-nova-scotia-closes-borders-to-non-essential-travel-from-most-of-canada/

On 3 may 2021, the provincial and territorial governments continue to be responsible for regulating long-term care (LTC) homes with the government of Canada providing guidance to protect residents and staff from covid-19. Measures to control the recent outbreak in Nova Scotia (NS) include: “no visitors or volunteers will be allowed inside long-term care facilities, except for designated care providers.” Some other provinces have relaxed visitor restrictions in long-term care homes now that almost all residents have been vaccinated. See Globe and Mail newspaper and government of NS websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503132100/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevent-control-covid-19-long-term-care-homes.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503132744/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/restriction-updates/

On 7 may 2021, the provincial and territorial governments continue to be responsible for regulating long-term care (LTC) homes with the government of Canada providing guidance to protect residents and staff from covid-19. Measures to protect residents during the recent outbreak in Nova Scotia (NS): “Long-term care facilities are closed to visitors, except for designated caregivers. Residents are not permitted to leave the facilities.” Some provinces have relaxed visitor restrictions in long-term care homes now that almost all residents have been vaccinated. See governments of Canada and NS websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507144954/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevent-control-covid-19-long-term-care-homes.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507145751/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/restriction-updates/

Changed to 1 to reflect the fact that Pandemic Unemployment Assistance is only available for 13 weeks. Non-formal workers can apply.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210522091749/https://www.dol.gov/coronavirus/unemployment-insurance

Government programs  are offering temporary COVID-19 assistance to pay rent, mortgages, and student loans. Food stamps and federal meal programs have also changed their rules to provide extra help during the coronavirus pandemic.    - If you're repaying a U.S. Department of Education-backed student loan, you're receiving forbearance. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic, your principal and interest payments have been automatically suspended through at least September 30, 2021.     - If you’ve been affected financially by the COVID-19 pandemic and you own a single-family home with a federally backed or FHA-insured mortgage, you can request mortgage forbearance, a pause in making mortgage payments.     - If you're out of work or lost income because of the COVID-19 pandemic, you may qualify for rental assistance through your state HUD program. And a federal eviction moratorium from the CDC, extended through June 30, 2021 may help you stay in your home if you can't pay your rent.     See list of Covid-19 financial assistance from the government - https://web.archive.org/web/20210508180340/https://www.usa.gov/covid-financial-help-from-the-government

According to the updated guidance, facilities should allow responsible indoor visitation at all times and for all residents, regardless of vaccination status of the resident, or visitor, unless certain scenarios arise that would limit visitation for:    Unvaccinated residents, if the COVID-19 county positivity rate is greater than 10 percent and less than 70 percent of residents in the facility are fully vaccinated;  Residents with confirmed COVID-19 infection, whether vaccinated or unvaccinated, until they have met the criteria to discontinue transmission-based precautions; or  Residents in quarantine, whether vaccinated or unvaccinated, until they have met criteria for release from quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210508181047/https://www.cms.gov/newsroom/press-releases/cms-updates-nursing-home-guidance-revised-visitation-recommendations
